Furthermore, good sons! Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain skillful means
and are complete.
What are the ten?
First, attaining skillful means of turning towards;
Second, skillful means of causing non-Buddhists to return and submit;
Third, skillful means of turning away from objects;
Fourth, skillful means of dispelling regret;
Fifth, skillful means of saving and protecting sentient beings;
Sixth, skillful means of giving sentient beings a means of livelihood;
Seventh, skillful means of receiving and accepting;
Eighth, skillful means of abandoning inappropriate situations and abiding in appropriate situations;
Ninth, skillful means of demonstrating, teaching, exhorting, and rejoicing;
Tenth, skillful means of making offerings and serving.
What is meant by a bodhisattva attaining skillful means of dedication?

It means that bodhisattvas, with flowers and fruits not taken from others, offer them to all buddhas and bodhisattvas six times a day and night, and dedicate this wholesome root to supreme, perfect enlightenment;

Bodhisattvas, with fragrant trees, precious trees, and kÄpÄ«la trees not taken from others, make offerings to all buddhas and bodhisattvas six times a day and night, and dedicate this wholesome root to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Bodhisattvas, with the vast service and offerings described in the sÅ«tras, upon hearing them, give rise to a mind of pure faith and joy, and dedicate these offerings to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Moreover, the bodhisattva is able to rejoice in the wholesome actions created by the bodhisattvas of the ten directions and other sentient beings, causing their provisions for enlightenment to be perfected, giving rise to pure thoughts and a deep mind of joy, and dedicating these wholesome roots to supreme, perfect enlightenment.

If the bodhisattva offers incense and flowers to the TathÄgata's stÅ«pa and Buddha image, dedicating this, may sentient beings be free from the defilements of broken precepts and attain the fragrance of the Buddha's precepts;

Moreover, the bodhisattvas offer flower canopies, dedicating this, may sentient beings abandon afflictions;

When lying on the right side, may it be like sentient beings abiding in nirvana;
When rising from lying down, may it be like sentient beings rising from the bonds of afflictions;
If going to the toilet, may it be like sentient beings heading towards the path of great enlightenment;
When actually defecating, may it be like sentient beings pulling out all the poisonous arrows;

Bodhisattvas themselves engage in various activities, and with this they dedicate [their merits] to benefit and comfort all sentient beings.
Bodhisattvas pay homage to the TathÄgata's stÅ«pas, wishing for sentient beings to always be revered by the gods and the world.

How do bodhisattvas skillfully cause non-Buddhists to submit?

Bodhisattvas are able to transform into various non-Buddhist forms within the various non-Buddhist groups, such as ÅšrÄvaka, PÄrá¹£va, ÅšÄkya, and Nirgrantha. They uphold and recite the teachings within those traditions.
Bodhisattvas, in order to bring sentient beings to maturity, think like this:
If I first become an ÄcÄrya, then I will not be able to cause arrogant sentient beings to submit to discipline.
Therefore, I will go to the non-Buddhist teachings and demonstrate leaving home to become their disciple.

Having gone forth, they diligently practiced various practices, extensively studied and learned, and thoroughly mastered their teachings. They begged for coarse and filthy food, and all their actions surpassed those of the non-Buddhist practitioners in terms of conduct and discipline.
Because of this, the non-Buddhist practitioners respected the bodhisattva as their teacher. They believed and accepted everything he said and followed his guidance.

The bodhisattva knew that these beings had turned to him, so he spoke about the faults of the non-Buddhist practitioners' wrong views and that the teachings they studied were not the true teachings, because they were unable to teach detachment from desire and its cessation.
Because of this, the non-Buddhist practitioners accepted the bodhisattva's guidance, abandoned their wrong paths, and entered the true teachings.
The bodhisattva also diligently practiced and attained the five supernormal powers among all the non-Buddhist practitioners who cultivated the brahma-conduct of the five supernormal powers.

Moreover, they cultivate and accomplish meditative absorptions, various samÄdhis, and samÄpattis, surpassing the five supernormal powers obtained by non-Buddhists, and their wisdom surpasses them, serving as their teacher.

The bodhisattvas, knowing that the non-Buddhists to be converted are all mature, explain the various faults of their meditative absorptions, various samÄdhis, and samÄpattis, and that the teachings they study are not the true teaching, because they do not teach the path of detachment from and elimination of desire.
Thus, the non-Buddhists, accepting the bodhisattvas' conversion, abandon the wrong path and enter the Buddha's teachings.
This is called the bodhisattvas' skillful means of causing non-Buddhists to turn toward [the Buddha's teachings].
What is the bodhisattvas' skillful means of turning away from objects?

It means that these bodhisattvas, observing all beings with much greed, skillfully subdue them by manifesting a female body that is upright and extremely beautiful, surpassing other female bodies, causing beings who see it to give rise to attachment.

Bodhisattvas see their attachment in this way, and then in their place of sleep they manifest death, in one instant, one muhÅ«rta, manifesting the appearance of bloating and rotting, foul and disgusting.
Sentient beings, having seen this, give rise to great fear and a distressed mind, deeply disgusted and abandoning [the body]:
Who can cause me to leave this filthy and disgusting place!
At that time, the bodhisattva then in front of them, according to their capacity, expounds such dharmas, definitely realizing one of the three kinds of enlightenment.
This is called the bodhisattva attaining the skillful means of abandoning through transformation.
What is the bodhisattva's skillful means of dispelling regret?
It is said that this bodhisattva sees sentient beings who have committed the five heinous crimes, and who have given rise to all kinds of unwholesome karma, losing their minds and regretting.
The bodhisattva goes to them and says like this:
'Good men!
How is it that you lose your minds and regretfully abide?'
Those sentient beings say:
'Great being!

I have committed various unwholesome actions that are uninterrupted, and I fear that for a long time I will experience suffering and distress, because of the lack of benefit and lack of peace and happiness.
For this reason, I have lost my mind and am remorseful.'
At that time, the bodhisattva extensively expounds the true Dharma for those sentient beings, causing them to deeply repent and accept the bodhisattva precepts.

If those sentient beings are still unable to repent, at that time the bodhisattva wishes to cause those people's minds to give rise to faith and submission, and manifests spiritual powers for them, extensively explaining the matters they should contemplate.
Sentient beings, because of this, give rise to a mind of faith and submission towards the bodhisattva, and with joy and delight in faith and enjoyment.
Having given rise to faith and enjoyment, their faculties mature, and the bodhisattva extensively expounds the wonderful Dharma for them, and they are then able to follow and accept it.
The bodhisattva also transforms the parents in front of those people and says these words:
'You should observe, I am your companion, a great man.
'You should not regret it. The karma you have created will definitely not lead to falling into the hells, nor will it cause you to lose benefits and happiness!'
Having said this, he then kills the parents he manifested.
The bodhisattva displays spiritual powers before those beings, and they think:
'Even the wise one who kills his parents does not lose his spiritual powers, let alone me, who lacks wisdom and creates this karma, falling into the hells and losing benefits and happiness!'
At that time, the bodhisattva expounds the wonderful Dharma for those beings, causing their evil karma to gradually become light, like a mosquito's wing.
This is called the bodhisattva's skillful means of dispelling regret.
What is the bodhisattva's skillful means of rescuing and protecting beings?
It means that this bodhisattva observes that the faculties and capacities of beings are mature and suitable for teaching the Dharma.

Those sentient beings create all kinds of extremely unwholesome karma. The bodhisattva, in order to benefit those people, skillfully tames them by manifesting various kinds of sentient beings. For those who should be tamed by the body of a great king, he manifests the body of a great king and preaches the Dharma for them;
for those who should be tamed by the body of a small king, he manifests the body of a small king and preaches the Dharma for them;
for those who should be tamed by the body of a brahmin or a kshatriya, he manifests the body of a brahmin or a kshatriya and preaches the Dharma for them;
for those who should be tamed by the body of a god, he manifests the body of a god and preaches the Dharma for them;
for those who should be tamed by the body of a vajra-holder, he manifests the body of a vajra-holder and preaches the Dharma for them;
for those who should be tamed by fear, he manifests fear and preaches the Dharma for them;
for those who should be tamed by binding, killing, beating, and scolding, he manifests such things and preaches the Dharma for them;
For those who should be tamed through loving speech, they manifest loving speech and expound the Dharma for them.
When sentient beings are about to commit various heinous crimes, they harbor thoughts of harm towards the body of a bodhisattva.
The bodhisattvas who have attained spiritual powers will manifest various skillful means for them, sometimes stopping them, sometimes restraining them, sometimes moving them to other places;

in front of those people, they will also manifest the appearance of committing heinous crimes, or manifest the appearance of a hell being, restraining the heinous crimes they are about to commit so that they do not manifest.

The bodhisattvas who have not yet attained spiritual powers are able to observe the length of the lifespans of those sentient beings. Seeing those sentient beings about to commit heinous crimes, they think like this:
These sentient beings are about to commit grave offenses.
They give rise to a mind of great compassion and feel distressed.
The bodhisattvas observe them as if they were holding an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of their hand, and think like this:ğŸ”½These sentient beings are about to commit heinous crimes.

'For the sake of benefiting a single sentient being, I am able to endure the great suffering of AvÄ«ci Hell. For this sentient being, until it abides in the nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, I am always able to do this without any other expedient means to stop it.

These sentient beings, having created evil karma, are about to be born in the hells. Because I have not yet attained the mastery of spiritual powers, I have no expedient means to move those unbelieving sentient beings with short lifespans and evil karma to other places, fearing that those sentient beings will be born in AvÄ«ci Hell due to their unwholesome karma!'

The Bodhisattva, giving rise to this compassionate mind, thinks that sentient beings each follow their own karma and there is no other expedient means to save them. He simply gives rise to a compassionate mind and impartially teaches and admonishes them, showing them punishment.
This is called the skillful means of Bodhisattvas in rescuing and protecting sentient beings.
What is the skillful means of Bodhisattvas in giving sentient beings the means to sustain life?

It means that bodhisattvas see sentient beings who are unable to accept the Dharma, who only seek clothing and food to satisfy themselves, and who are unable to understand the holy Dharma and self-discipline.
Bodhisattvas teach these sentient beings mathematics, skills, writing, and record-keeping, such activities, in order to accomplish goodness and not accomplish unwholesome dharmas.
This is called the bodhisattvas' skillful means of giving sentient beings a means of livelihood.
How do bodhisattvas attain the skillful means of acceptance?

It means that these bodhisattvas attain a heap of precious jewels like a wondrous mountain but do not accept it, but if they attain inferior miscellaneous necessities of life they immediately accept them.
Why is this?
It means that these bodhisattvas think like this:

'These sentient beings are obscured by stinginess, jealousy, and greed, sparing their own and others' possessions, not allowing themselves and others to enjoy them, and for this reason they are always drowning in the ocean of birth and death.

In order to enable those sentient beings to obtain complete benefits and happiness for a long time, the bodhisattva then accepts it. Although he accepts their things, he does not give rise to craving or attachment, and has no mind of his own. He only makes offerings to the Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha, enabling all sentient beings to obtain victory together, and to benefit the poor and suffering sentient beings. Because of this, the donors rejoice and leap with joy.
This is called the bodhisattva's skillful means of accepting and taking.
What is the bodhisattva's skillful means of abandoning inappropriate places and abiding in appropriate places?

It means that the bodhisattvas observe sentient beings who are able to receive the Dharma and should manifest perfect enlightenment in unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment, but those sentient beings give rise to the expedient means of attaining the vehicle of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, and always diligently cultivate and practice them.
The bodhisattvas expound the Dharma to enable those sentient beings to abandon the two vehicles and lead them to turn towards the Dharma of the Great Vehicle.
This is called the bodhisattvas' skillful means of abandoning inappropriate situations and abiding in appropriate situations.
What is the bodhisattvas' skillful means of demonstrating, teaching, inspiring, and gladdening?
It means that the bodhisattvas can cause sentient beings who have not yet given rise to the mind of enlightenment to give rise to the mind of enlightenment;

those who have already given rise to the mind of enlightenment, although they may uphold the precepts and easily be content, if they have little vigor and much laziness, the bodhisattvas teach them to always cultivate vigor.

If there are sentient beings who, although they uphold the precepts a little, violate them a lot, due to this cause and condition, their faith is impure, they always lack joy and delight, and their minds are covered by the defilements of breaking the precepts.
The bodhisattvas expound various wonderful teachings for those sentient beings, causing their minds to give rise to pure faith, joy, and delight.

How do bodhisattvas attain skillful means in serving and making offerings?
It is said that bodhisattvas, having gone forth, know the proper amount and are content with the offerings they receive, and the offerings they receive are not contrary to the Dharma.

What is a bodhisattva's vow of non-inferiority?
It means that a bodhisattva does not delight in any existence but makes a vow. This is called a bodhisattva's vow of non-inferiority.

It means that a bodhisattva does not detest the three realms, does not seek to be free from desire, and abides in tranquility, but makes a vow. This is called a bodhisattva's vow of non-cowardice.

'Until the realm of sentient beings has all given rise to the bodhi mind, may they all give rise to the bodhi mind;

having successively cultivated the practices, may they sit under the bodhi tree. For those who have already attained the seat of enlightenment, I will serve, respect, and make offerings to them, requesting them to turn the wheel of the Dharma;

That is to say, this bodhisattva does not depend on others to make a vow regarding supreme, perfect enlightenment.

What is the bodhisattva's attainment of the boundless vow?

That is to say, this bodhisattva does not make a vow for the sake of a small amount of provisions for enlightenment, but rather this bodhisattva makes a great vow, covering the left shoulder, touching the right knee to the ground, giving rise to pure faith, contemplating the buddhas and all bodhisattvas dwelling in the ten directions of the world, some bodhisattvas abiding in ascetic practices, some sitting in the place of enlightenment, some seeing the buddhas, some manifesting perfect enlightenment, some turning the wheel of the Dharma. Having seen them, giving rise to pure intention, towards those buddhas and bodhisattvas in the ten directions, whether abiding in ascetic practices, manifesting perfect enlightenment, or turning the wheel of the Dharma, the bodhisattva deeply rejoices in faith and understanding towards each and every one of them, dedicating it to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
This is called the bodhisattva attaining the boundless vow.
What is the bodhisattva's vow of not being frightened?

It means that when bodhisattvas first generate the mind [of enlightenment], they hear the profound Dharma, hear the vast and great majestic virtue of the buddhas, hear the bodhisattvas playing with spiritual powers, and hear the profound skillful means and skillful methods. When the bodhisattvas hear this, they are not startled or frightened, and think like this:

The enlightenment realized by the tathÄgatas, the realm in which they abide, and the maturation of sentient beings are all boundless and immeasurable. I am unable to know those dharmas, but the buddhas have realized and know them, and I should also know them.
This is called the bodhisattvas' vow not to be startled or frightened.
What is the bodhisattvas' vow not to be weary or exhausted?
It means that although the bodhisattvas see sentient beings with stubborn and foolish dispositions that are difficult to subdue, they never become weary or exhausted with those sentient beings.
There are some bodhisattvas who, seeing sentient beings with stubborn and foolish dispositions that are difficult to subdue, become weary and exhausted;
because of weariness and exhaustion, they abandon sentient beings and make such a vow:
'I seek to be born in a pure world, and will never hear the names of such evil beings;
Although I wish to be born in a pure world, I will never be able to be born there, because I have abandoned sentient beings and not brought them to maturity.'
In this meaning, the wise bodhisattva gives rise to this thought:

'Among the sentient beings in all worlds, those with inferior diligence and laziness, those who are dull, deaf, blind, and mute like dumb sheep, such sentient beings are observed and examined by all Buddhas and bodhisattvas, and those who have no Dharma of parinirvÄá¹‡a are all abandoned.
I now wish to gather all such sentient beings in my Buddha land, and I wish to cause these sentient beings to sit at the site of enlightenment and attain supreme perfect enlightenment.'
When this bodhisattva gives rise to such thoughts and reflections, the palaces of all mÄras will quake in every moment, and he will be praised by all buddhas, tathÄgatas.
Such a bodhisattva will definitely be born in a pure buddha land and will be able to quickly manifest perfect enlightenment in unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
This is called the bodhisattva's vow of non-exhaustion.
What is the bodhisattva's vow of fulfillment?
It means that when this bodhisattva sits at the site of enlightenment, he destroys the armies of MÄra and manifests perfect enlightenment in the path of unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
When the vow is fulfilled, he does not give rise to it again.
Good man!
It is like ghee or oil completely filling a bowl, not allowing any more to be received, even as little as a drop. Therefore it is called the vow of fulfillment.
Bodhisattvas are like a bowl filled with ghee or oil. Having realized perfect enlightenment, their vows are fulfilled and they do not make any more wonderful vows.
This is called the bodhisattvas' attainment of perfect vows.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas attain the perfection of great vows.

What is meant by a bodhisattva's perfection of the power of practice that cannot be obscured by others?
It means that this bodhisattva cannot be obscured by any non-Buddhist or heterodox teachings. This is called the perfection of the power of practice that cannot be obscured by others.
What is meant by a bodhisattva's perfection of the power of invincibility?
It means that among all sentient beings, there is none who can overpower a bodhisattva's power. This is called the perfection of the power of invincibility.
What is meant by a bodhisattva's perfection of the cultivation of the power of merit?

It means that this bodhisattva cultivates all the worldly and transcendent merits, and accumulates all the provisions for enlightenment without the slightest incompleteness. This is called a bodhisattva's perfection of the cultivation of the power of merit.

It is said that bodhisattvas observe all buddha-dharmas with correct prajÃ±Ä, except for the TathÄgata's omniscience, which they have not yet realized or fully understood. This is called bodhisattvas' perfection of the power of prajÃ±Ä.
How do bodhisattvas equally perfect the power of their retinue?

It is said that all the retinue of these bodhisattvas are perfect in precepts, views, deportment, and pure livelihood. All the retinue equally practice the same as the bodhisattvas. This is called bodhisattvas' equal perfection of the power of their retinue.
How do bodhisattvas perfect the power of spiritual abilities?

That is to say, this bodhisattva's power of spiritual penetrations surpasses the realms of spiritual penetrations of all worldly beings and the two vehicles. The bodhisattva wishes to place JambudvÄ«pa, up to the four continents, a world system of a thousand worlds, a world system of two-thousand worlds, a world system of three-thousand great thousand worlds, on a single hair-tip.

Moreover, the bodhisattva wishes to place immeasurable Ganges-river-sands worlds in the space of a single atom. Such worlds, whether two, three, four, five, or ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, up to inexpressibly inexpressible, inexpressibly inexpressible, inexpressibly inexpressible, Ganges-river-sands worlds, are placed in a single minute atom.

The size of the atom does not increase or decrease, and those worlds, each placed in a single atom, do not obstruct each other, and the beings therein are also without the appearance of disturbance, oppression, or confinement.
This is called the bodhisattva's perfect attainment of the power of spiritual penetrations.
How do bodhisattvas perfect the power of mastery?
It means that when a bodhisattva wishes to fill a trichiliocosm with the seven treasures to benefit sentient beings, or even to fill innumerable worlds with various treasures,
this is called the bodhisattvas' perfection of the power of mastery.

This is called the bodhisattva's attainment of the perfection of spiritual power that is unalterable.

That is to say, the instructions and words of this bodhisattva are without duality, and sentient beings trust and obey them without transgression, except for skillful means and skillful benefit and joy.
This is called the bodhisattva's attainment of the perfection of the power of unerring instruction.

Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten kinds of dharmas perfect the practice of power.

Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain the perfection of wisdom.

third, attaining perfection in immeasurable wisdom;
fourth, attaining perfection in the wisdom that is the domain of samÄdhi;

How does a bodhisattva attain perfection in the wisdom of the non-self of persons?
This bodhisattva observes the arising of the characteristics of the various aggregates, and also observes the destruction of the aggregates.
When a bodhisattva correctly observes the arising of the aggregates, their nature is not solid and has no real function, which is precisely emptiness;
and correctly observes the destruction of the aggregates.
The bodhisattva thinks like this:
'The aggregates are ultimately without self, also without sentient beings, without life, without nourishment, and without pudgala.
Foolish ordinary beings are attached to the self.
' Thinking like this:

'The aggregates are not the self, the self is not the aggregates, yet in the aggregates there is a false attachment to the self, because one is unable to understand the true Dharma, birth and death flow and turn like a revolving wheel.'
The bodhisattva truly understands all dharmas, this is called the bodhisattva's perfect attainment of the wisdom of the non-self of pudgala.
How does the bodhisattva attain perfect completion of the wisdom of the non-self of dharmas?
It means that this bodhisattva truly understands the nature of increasing and decreasing all dharmas.
The bodhisattva further thinks like this:

'The Dharma and names are mutually guests. It is only due to false discrimination that the Dharma and names are established, both being without intrinsic nature. The bodhisattva truly understands that all things arise in dependence on conditions, and cease when conditions end.

What is meant by the bodhisattva's perfect attainment of immeasurable wisdom?
It means that this bodhisattva's immeasurable wisdom does not arise in the first moment and not arise in subsequent moments;
It does not arise in this place and not arise in other places.
Because unobstructed wisdom is always continuous and universally arises in all moments and all places.
This is called the bodhisattva's perfect attainment of immeasurable wisdom.

The bodhisattva perfects ten dharmas and attains equality with the great earth.
What are the ten?
First, it is vast and immeasurable;
Second, it is enjoyed by all sentient beings;
Third, it abandons enmity;
Fourth, it can universally receive the great Dharma rain;
Fifth, it is the reliance of all sentient beings;
Sixth, it is the basis of all wholesome seeds;
Seventh, it is like a great treasure vessel;
Eighth, it is like a great medicine vessel;
Ninth, it is unshakable;
Tenth, it is fearless.
Good man!
How is it that bodhisattvas are vast and immeasurable?
Just as the great earth is vast and boundless,
Bodhisattvas are like this, vast and boundless, with immeasurable blessings and wisdom.
This is called the bodhisattvas attaining vastness and immeasurability.
How is it that bodhisattvas are enjoyed by all sentient beings?
It is like the great earth, which is the support for various necessities, enjoyed by all sentient beings.
In the same way, the bodhisattva gathers various provisions such as giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom, which are enjoyed by sentient beings.
This is called the bodhisattva being enjoyed by all sentient beings.
How does the bodhisattva abandon gratitude and resentment?
Good man!
It is like the great earth, which equally supports and nurtures without gratitude, resentment, anger, or various thoughts of joy.
In the same way, the bodhisattva has no gratitude or resentment towards sentient beings, and does not give rise to anger or joy.
This is called the bodhisattva abandoning gratitude and resentment.
How does the bodhisattva universally receive the great Dharma clouds and rain?
It is like the great earth, which universally receives the vast clouds and rain, and fully contains them all.

This is called the bodhisattvas' all-encompassing reception of the great Dharma clouds and rains.

Bodhisattvas are like this, able to be the basis for all the good dharmas of sentient beings.
This is called the bodhisattvas' being the basis for all good seeds.
How are bodhisattvas like great treasure vessels?
Good man!
It is like the great earth, which can manifest various precious treasures because it is the vessel for all treasures.
Bodhisattvas are like this, able to manifest various meritorious treasures.
This is called the bodhisattvas being like a great vessel for treasures.
How are bodhisattvas like a great vessel for medicine?
Good man!
It is like the great earth, which gives rise to all medicines and can cure all illnesses in the world.
Bodhisattvas are like this, giving rise to the great medicines of the Dharma, and the medicines of the Dharma they manifest can extinguish the afflictions and illnesses of the world.
This is called the bodhisattvas being like a great vessel for medicine.
How do bodhisattvas attain imperturbability?
Good man!
It is like the great earth, which is not damaged by the power of mosquitoes, flies, and so forth, and cannot be shaken by worldly winds.
Bodhisattvas are like this, not swayed by the inner and outer sufferings of all beings.
This is called the bodhisattvas attaining imperturbability.
What is meant by bodhisattvas being unafraid?
Good man!
It is like the great earth, where even if there are the sounds of dragons and the king of beasts roaring, there is no fear.
Bodhisattvas are like this. Even if they hear the roaring sounds of all demons and non-Buddhists, they do not become frightened.
This is called bodhisattvas being unafraid.
Good man!
